title: Remove README.md doc attribute in lib.rs

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: size:XS
labels.description: This PR changes 0-9 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
It appears that  `#![doc = include_str!("../../README.md")]` in `lib.rs` does not work now that we have workspaced packages. It works fine during development, but when building and publishing releases, we get:

```
   Compiling slatedb v0.8.0 (/home/runner/work/slatedb/slatedb/target/package/slatedb-0.8.0)
error: couldn't read `src/../../README.md`: No such file or directory (os error 2)
 --> src/lib.rs:1:10
  |
1 | #![doc = include_str!("../../README.md")]
  |          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  |
help: there is a file with the same name in a different directory
  |
1 | #![doc = include_str!("../../../../README.md")]
  |                              ++++++
```

This can be replicated locally with:

```
cargo publish --dry-run -p slatedb
```

It seems that we removed the doc include after 0.6.1. I re-added it here (assuming it would work):

https://github.com/slatedb/slatedb/commit/82847c76d07c4701cc63994091bcf087bb113c68

Turns out that was a bad assumption. I fiddled with things for an hour but couldn't figure out how to get it to work both in the IDE/dev environment and also at build time.

title: Retry sst put requests on Timeout.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
If the object store returns a time out writing SSTs on the remote store, retry the operation.

The retry uses a backoff strategy that will retry again at most for 3 more times.

I'm opening this as a draft for now because I'm investigating how we can have mocked server behaviors that would trigger a timeout response.

See #766

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
### What
This PR aims to refactor the code to Make iterator creation concurrent. This would help parallelize I/O operations and could help improve end to end latency of the scan query

### Changes
1. Write a generic method in utils.rs that takes a generic input of (source_ssts, async function) and return a list of created iterators.
2. Updated code to use the above method in reader.rs `scan_with_options` function.
3.  Updated code to use the above method in compactor_executor.rs `lload_iterators` function.

### References
https://github.com/slatedb/slatedb/issues/814
https://github.com/slatedb/slatedb/pull/784/files

title: Add `MessageDispatcher` to standardize background task event loop logic

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XXL
labels.description: This PR changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
We have many separate background tasks in SlateDB:

- `mem_table_flush.rs` flushes memtables, handles checkpoint creation (sometimes), and refreshes `Db`'s in-memory manifest.
- `db_reader.rs` refreshes the in-memory `DbReader`s manifest.
- `compactor.rs` schedules compactions and checks the executor channel for responses.
- `garbage_collector.rs` handles garbage collection.
- `batch_write.rs` receives write requests and sends them to the WAL buffer and active (in-memory) mem table.
- `wal_buffer.rs` receives write requests and writes to the WAL.

Each one of these files has a bespoke (and often _very_ complex) `spawn_*` method. Yet each of these methods are largely doing the same set of things:

1. Handling messages from a channel
2. Handling clock ticker ticks
3. Handling failures (updating `DbState::error`, draining remaining messages, notifying remaining listeners, and so on)

I find these `spawn_` methods very difficult to understand and debug. In 0.7.0, we had multiple issues that stemmed from mismanagement of these event loops and their channels.

This PR aims to remove some of this complexity by providing a standard event loop implementation called `MessageDispatcher`. The dispatcher is responsible for managing the event loop lifecycle. Dispatchers are _not_ responsible for processing logic; that responsibility is delegated to `MessageHandler`s, which implement callbacks to handle event processing, tickers, and resource cleanup.

title: Shutdown cleanly in `test_concurrent_writers_and_readers`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
It looks like we were not doing a clean shutdown in `test_concurrent_writers_and_readers`. Instead, we were calling `abort()` on the reader threads and then ignoring errors returned by the reader tasks.

This PR updates the code to use a cancellation token to shutdown cleanly and then verify the readers have no errors.

Fixes #806

this pr prepared the conflict checking logics in the implementation of SI transaction.

this pr should not affect all the exisiting behaviour: when there's no active non-readonly transactions, no `recent_committed_txn` is tracked in memory at all.

active non-readonly transaction is only possible to exists after `DbTransaction` interface is introduced, which is planned in a seperated issue #816.

title: Clean up nightly.yaml so it passes and notifies on failure

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
I noticed that...

- Our nightly.yaml ZeroFS tests have been failing for a while
- Our nightly.yaml charts for benchmarks are only posting the first and last runs in the chart.
- I didn't notice these failures sooner.

I'm updating our nightly to:

1. Always use the latest clean ZeroFS checksum (rather than hardcoding it). This won't fix things permanently, since ZeroFS might not be working off SlateDB HEAD, but it should be close.
2. Vibe coded a fix for the charts. We'll see.
3. Added a notify step that opens a GH issue when nightly fails, and comments on adds a comment on an open issue if it already exists.

title: refactor(memtable): remove mutable reference for `put` method

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Maintenance work

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
Original #774.

Due to interior mutability and the fact that SkipMap is lock-free, `WritableKVTable::put` does not require mutable reference. Similarly, `DbState::memtable` does not require mutable reference (since we do not modify the `DbState.memtable` field).

This allows us to improve concurrency (otherwise, each `WriteBatch` operation would block other operations that modify `DbState`)

title: Apply batch operations in DST after writing to the database.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: size:S
labels.description: This PR changes 10-29 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
Currently, the state of the DST is modified before a write batch hits the database. This could create inconsistencies where the state changes, but the database doesn't change because there was an error writing to it.

This change the order of operations to apply the write batch to the state only after the write to the database successfully completes.

title: fix(snapshot): not use `Option` on recent_snapshot_min_seq

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
currently we use to use a eventual consistency manner to flush the `recent_snapshot_min_seq` to inform the compactor not to reclaim the data that's possible to be accessed by living snapshots.

however, there might contain a bug in the implementation: what if `recent_snapshot_min_seq` not get flushed in time, but compactor find its `None` in manifest, so compactor may mistakely recycle the versioned data that actively accessed by living snapshots.

this pr try to fix this issue by not regarding `recent_snapshot_min_seq` as an `Option`, but a somewhat monotonic increasing number. instead of maintain this value on snapshots created/dropped, ~this value can also be updated after every commit to ensure it's monotonic increasing~ this value is updated whenever memtable is flushed to l0: if there's active snapshots, it take the min seq of these snapshots, otherwise take `last_l0_seq`.

any feedback is appreciated!

title: Limit nightly DST to 12 minutes

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XS
labels.description: This PR changes 0-9 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
We are running out of disk space in our nightly DSTs. The reason appears to be that the `LocalFilesystem` `object_store` uses the actual timestamps from the machine time. Our DST mock system clock starts at the UTC epoch, though. Consequently, all the files have a last modified time _way_ ahead of our mock system clock. This causes the GC not to ever remove anything.

I plan to open a GH issue to figure out what to do about this. In the meantime, I'm limiting the nightly DST execution time to 12 minutes so we don't run out of disk on the WarpBuild machine.

title: Switching perf charts to mermaid diagrams

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
#731 migrated us away from the slatedb-website repo. This repo is where we were housing charts from the [github-action-benchmark](https://github.com/benchmark-action/github-action-benchmark) action.

Now that we're housing the website in main (and using GH environments not the `gh-pages` branch), I no longer want the action to commit into the main repo to update the chart data. I've decided to update `benchmark-db.sh` to produce mermaid [xyChart](https://mermaid.js.org/syntax/xyChart.html) files. If the chart files already exist, the shell script appends the latest run to the chart; otherwise, it creates a chart with a single data point.

I've then updated `nightly.yaml` to save the charts on each run and post them to the Github action summary block.

You can play with the charts [here](https://www.mermaidchart.com/play), too.

labels.name: enhancement

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body: This PR adds a new environment variable for DSTs called `SLATEDB_DST_ROOT`. The `slow` DST uses this as the root to create a `LocalFileSystem` `object_store` for each `Db`. Previously, we were using `InMemory`, which was accruing a ton of memory because GC wasn't running very frequently and we were creating a ton of garbage in the test.

title: [2/4] implementation of gorilla-based single tier sequence tracker

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XL
labels.description: This PR changes 500-999 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
See #710 for the full context and how this is wired in.

This PR adds a data structure that can help track a map of sequence number -> timestamp with lossy granularity. 

Some notes:

1. It encodes using the Gorilla encoding strategy. Unfortunately I couldn't find a well maintained rust implementation of it, and it isn't too much code to just vendor it so I implemented it here. 
2. Gorilla recommends storing timestamps with second granularity to reduce the delta-of-deltas. I do that here by converting all timestamps to seconds. This is probably fine as this map is intended to be used for operational use cases.
3. The current implementation only supports a single tier with even spacing. When it fills up it downsamples everything. This is likely not the ideal final behavior as we likely want newer datapoints to be stored with higher granularity, which is what I'm intending to do with the tiered approach.

title: Add a nightly DST test

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
This PR integrates the DST into the nightly Github workflow.

- Adds a `test_dst_nightly` test to simulation.rs.
- Adds a `slow` cfg to `Cargo.toml` to signal slow tests should be run.
- Updates `nightly.yaml` to run the DST on a WarpBuild instance.
- Adds a `DstDuration` param that can be either `Iterations` or `Duration` (wall-clock time) to the `run_simulation`. This allows us to run simulations for a set amount of time rather than a set number of iterations.
- Update `nextest.toml` to include a new `dst-nightly` profile.
- Update docs and README.md

`test_dst_nightly` runs a separate DST on each core of the host machine. The tests run in parallel for 50 minutes.

Future improvements:

- Fail as soon as a handle finishes rather than joining them sequentially.
- Make `test_dst_nightly` use an environment variable so the 50m duration isn't hard-coded.

title: Remove structured logging

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Maintenance work

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
I thought #706 would fix our structured logging problems. The issue began when I migrated to `log` for all logging (#702). After doing so, we couldn't see structured log fields using `tracing_subscriber`. I thought I fixed the issue in #706, but the structured log k-v fields were still not visible (I misread the log output). After #706, I dug into the code and realized that `tracing_log` does not use `log::Record::key_values()` at all; they're just dropped.

I opened https://github.com/tokio-rs/tracing/issues/3355 to see if we can get structured log support for the `log` crate into `tracing_log`. In the meantime, I've replaced all structured logging with normal string interpolation style logs.

I also took the opportunity to do some minor log standardization as I came across it (lowercase case letters, wrap params in `[]` at end of file (e.g. `some error happened [path={:?}, error={}]`. This loosely aligns with the `error.rs` guidance that @calavera outlined. My changes are not exhaustive, but clean up things quite a bit already.

The alternative I considered was just going back to `tracing` for logs. I'm not strongly opposed to this, but it doesn't seem ideal since SlateDB is a library that's meant to be unopinionated about the environment/application it runs in.

title: [refactor] make modifying COW state easier

title: Prevent ticker starvation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
I'm updating the `SystemClockTicker` behavior to include the time since last tick when calculating its `sleep()` time. Previously, it was always using the fixed `duration` that was provided to the constructor. This is inaccurate, though, since time passes between `tick()` invocations; in some cases, by a lot.

The new behavior is to sleep for `duration - elapsed`, where `elapsed` is `now - last_tick`. So, a duration of 500ms and a last tick of 2000ms and a now of 2200ms would sleep for 300ms (`500 - (2200-2000)`). If the deadline is exceeded (now > last_tick + duration), the ticker ticks immediately (by sleeping 0ms). I think this mirrors the `delay` behavior in [`MissedTickBehavior`](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/time/enum.MissedTickBehavior.html).

```
Expected ticks: |     1     |     2     |     3     |     4     |     5     |     6     |
Actual ticks:   | work -----|          delay          | work -----| work -----| work -----|
```

I also discovered we can get by without having a `&mut self` reference for the function. We could have done this before if I'd used `AtomicBool`, but I didn't think to do so. Now that we're using `AtomicI64` as the last_tick type, we can drop the mut. This also appears to mean we can elide the `'a` lifetime in the returned future. I don't fully understand the magic going on there.

Finally, I had to tweak `test_flush_with_options_wal`. There was a race condition I didn't realize (thanks LLM), where the manifest_poll_interval can tick in the mem_table_flusher immediately. This should have been triggered before, but I suspect it was just a smidge slower. Now, the manifest_poll_interval ticks between the initial and final stat checks, which increments the counter non-deterministically. I fixed this by forcing mem table flushes to fail (with fail_parallel) and simply checking the DB is not in an error state after we're all done flushing the WAL.

Fixes #705

title: Consume log events into tracing (including structured logs)

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:S
labels.description: This PR changes 10-29 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
When I converted `tracing::` logs to `log::` logs, I ported the structured logging as well, assuming it would work. It turns out the default tracing_subscriber configuration does not properly consume the key-value pairs from the `log` library by default. We need to use `LogTracer` from the `tracing_log` crate (provided by the tracing library) to have these key-value pairs properly consumed. This PR updates accordingly.

See https://github.com/tokio-rs/tracing/discussions/2875 for some more notes.

We should be using the `logs` facade crate everywhere in `slatedb` since it's a library. I added clippy macro checks to enforce this and updated the code accordingly.

I left the tracing_subscriber (vs. env_logger or others) for output in tests and tools since that's what `opendal` does and I didn't want to overthink things. I also left the -cli and -bencher crates to continue using `tracing` for their logs since they're applications, not libraries.

I also took the opportunity to prevent...

- stdout print's
- Option::unwrap
- Result::unwrap

title: feat(snapshot): add retention min seq to manifest

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
as discussed in #638, we plan to track the `retention min seq` in the manifest during running transactions, and let the compactor get the `retention min seq` via the manifest, so the compactor can safely cleanup the data not actively accessed by snapshots/transactions.

this PR adds a `retention_min_seq` field to the manifest, and enables this field for compactor. however, this pr is expected not to change the existing behavior, until we add logics to flush this field to manifest.

this PR can also be considered as a subtask extracted from #688. #688 should later add a method to flush the `retention_min_seq` to the manifest in the background.

title: Add `gen_ulid` clock param

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
I found that our current ULID generator is non-deterministic because it uses the `ulid` crate to get time, which always uses system time, not our `SystemClock`. Fixed this by adding a param to take our clock.

I considered separating ULID and UUID generation out so we can have a ULID struct that contains a clock, but it felt clunky to have two different ways to generate IDs. This way, the ULID and UUID generation continue to piggyback off of any `RngCore`, and we only need to pass a clock when we're generating ULIDs, which is relatively limited.

title: Add `flush_with_options` to enable manual memtable flushing

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
Some users wish to control memtable flushes even when the WAL is enabled. See #684 for some use cases.

I've added a `flush_with_options` to allow users to trigger flushes with either the WAL or memtable.

- `flush_with_options(FlushOptions { flush_type: FlushType::MemTable })` will...
   - freeze the active WAL, and then...
   - flush all immutable WAL KVTables to disk, and then...
   - block until the flush is complete
- `flush_with_options(FlushOptions { flush_type: FlushType::MemTable })` will...
   - return a `WalDisabled` error if the WAL is disabled, or else...
   - freeze the active memtable KVTable, and then...
   - flush all immutable memtables, and then...
   - block until the flush is complete

Flushing the WAL will not trigger a memtable flush, and flushing the memtable will not trigger a WAL flush. I verified that triggering a memtable flush without triggering the WAL flush is safe becasue we have `replay_after_wal_id` and `last_l0_seq` in the manifest. On replay, we filter out (by `<= last_l0_seq`) records from the WAL that are already durably written to an L0 SST.

#680 is a bit related. In that PR, I initially made `flush_interval` fall back to the memtable if `wal_enabled=false`. That approach doesn't solve the problem in #684, though. Users still wouldn't be able to trigger memtable flushes if the WAL is enabled.

Fixes #684

title: Implement the Public Error API.

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XXL
labels.description: This PR changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
This is an implementation of RFC 7, but with caveats.

When I started implementing it, I realized that it lacked some details on the design itself. I opted for changing the `Error` type definition to match what I've seen in other very popular crates, instead of using an enum to define all the errors, the `Error` type is a generic error that includes a `ErrorKind` enum with the different error variants. This is similar to the implementation that the AWS SDK follows, for example.

I also added a section to the RFC about internal vs external errors, and how to format errors to be consistent across the board. We can use that as a guideline when we introduce new errors, I noticed that there were a lot of variations in format, and I think it's better to constraint ourselves to some clear guidelines.

This is a short summary of what this massive PR includes:

- Update the RFC with more information about error types and formatting.
- Create the new public Error type.
- Create a transformation between SlateDBError and the new Error type.
- Update all public endpoint to use the new Error type.
- Update abstract internal errors to be more specific.

Fixes #508

title: Add deterministic simulation tests to SlateDB

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XXL
labels.description: This PR changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
A `slatedb-dst` package is added in this PR. The package contains dst.rs, which contains a deterministic simulator that runs random operations against a SlateDB instance and verifies that the DB has the correct data. Several integration tests are available in `simulation.rs`; they've been added to the `pr.yaml` check, too. See the README.md, dst.rs docs, and simulations.rs docs for usage and implementation details.

There is still much to be done to improve the simulation tests:

- Add unit tests to dst.rs to verify method behavior.
- Add a CLI to trigger DST's outside of `cargo`
- Incorporate DSTs into the `nightly.yaml`
- Complete the `TODO`s to add more randomness and configuration
- Add TTL, checkpointing, DbReader, and fencing (multi-writer), and DB close/open checks and actions
- Incorporate the object store file cache and inject faults in the filesystem
- Inject faults in the object store requests
- Evaluate using proptest to build DB settings and generate random data
- Verify log output is identical in `test_dst_is_deterministic` (we only verify final seed and times are identical)

Still, I feel this is a good start and the PR is already fairly lengthy. I'd like to do the CLI and nightly.yaml as follow-ons. The remaining items can be completed over time.

While running the tests, I discovered two instances of non-determinism in SlateDB:

- The compactor was using `spawn_blocking` to start and stop compactions with the executor. I assumed `spawn_blocking` would be deterministic, but it turns out not to be. It spawns outside the `current_thread` Tokio runtime and creates a non-deterministic race between `.await` calls in the `current_thread` and those in the spawned thread. I fixed this by adding a branch for `#[cfg(dst)]` that uses tokio's `spawn`, which runs on the runtime threads. I opted not to use `spawn` for production code because we can't trust pluggable executors not to block for a long time on start/stop compaction calls; they could block our runtime threads.
- ULID was using the RNG to deterministically generate the random portion of its bytes, but was still using its own clock for the timestamp portion. I fixed this by adding a `timestamp_ms` field to `gen_ulid`.

I found the following resources helpful when doing this work:

- https://pierrezemb.fr/posts/tokio-hidden-gems/
- https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/1jr8ogo/comment/mle11wh/
- https://s2.dev/blog/dst

Fixes #267

title: feat: add DbSnapshot

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XXL
labels.description: This PR changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
this pr aims to add the API for creating snapshot.

a `DbSnapshot` contains all the read-only operations in a `Db` object. it records the seqnum at the moment when the `DbSnapshot` is created, and always making a consistent view as long as this `DbSnapshot` object lives.

in the current design, `DbSnapshot` is not expected to work on the db read instance.

we can divide this pr into the following subtasks:

- [x] scan() get() with `seq` passed
- [x] track all the living `DbSnapshot` objects (maybe in a `TransactionManager`?)
- [x] extract the `min_retention_seq` from living `DbSnapshot` objects, and persist it in manifest (flushed whenever memtable flushes)
- [x] let the compactor handle the `min_retention_seq` by RetentionIterator #701
- [x] exposing the API
- [x] add tests

title: Replace `SystemTime` with `DateTime<Utc>` in `SystemClock::now()`

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:L
labels.description: This PR changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
This is a follow-on to https://github.com/slatedb/slatedb/pull/683#discussion_r2216100284. In that PR, @dmvk raised a concern about code smell around the system_time util functions. I did some investigation and considered:

1. Leaving things as they are
2. Doing`SystemTime::now() -> i64`
3. Doing `SystemTime::now() -> EpochMs` (our own struct that wraps an i64)
4. Using `Chrono::DateTime<Utc>`

The SystemTime stuff is a bit janky because we can't create a SystemTime with our own `i64`. Moreover, they require a lot of things to be u64, which is frustrating since we're supporting negative timestamps (it's debatable whether we should do this, I suppose). The `std::time` API just kinda sucks, too.

I really don't like (2), since it makes it even _more_ likely for us to goof up timestamps between logical and system clocks (see #685). I plan to further separate the two by adding a `struct LogicalTimestamp(i64)` and having `LogicalClock::now()` return the struct instead of a raw `i64`. This will further insulate us from these kinds of mistakes.

(3) is what I started doing, but ultimately, I landed on Chrono's `DateTime<Utc>`. When I built `EpochMs`, it just became a degenerate form of what `DateTime<Utc>` already is. I also noticed that both `object_store` and `opendal` expose `DateTime<Utc>` as their tiemstamps in public APIs, so I think we're in good company here.

/cc @xuanwo Any feedback on your experience with `DateTime<Utc>` in OpenDAL?

title: Remove tokio::time usage

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: size:XL
labels.description: This PR changes 500-999 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
I thought it would be OK to continue to use `tokio::time` directly in SlateDB since we can pause/resume it in tests (e.g. with `start_paused=true`. Unfortunately, I found an issue with that when working on some deterministic simulation tests. The issue arises if you want to run a simulation test twice as though it were the same point in time. Unfortunately, Tokio's `time` module does not allow users to set a time in the past, only to advance it.

This PR goes through the code to replace (almost) all usage of `tokio::time` methods and types with our `SystemClock` trait. To accomplish all that tokio does for us, I had to introduce some new methods to our system clock: advance, sleep, and ticker. I opted to replace`timeout` usage witha  `tokio::select!` rather than fight with Rust's lifetime stuff more. If people strongly object lacking a `timeout` method, I can revisit it.

There are a few places where `tokio::time` is still used. All are in tests, and they're fairly harmless. Some day maybe we can scrub the remaining ones, but this PR is already quite large.

This PR also introduces `MockSystemClock`, which is a mock clock that's completely divorced from Tokio's time as well as std::time. It's entirely self-encapsulated, and allows users to set any time they want. This is the clock I use in my DST branch, and it seems to work quite nicely.

I've also added tests for both the default and mock system clocks.

Note that the mock clock is only available when SlateDB's `test-util` feature is enabled (this is a new feature in this PR). I had to go this route because DST is done in the `slatedb-dst` crate, which only has access to public APIs in SlateDB. Otherwise, I would have simply used `#[cfg(test)]`. The `test-util` follows Tokio's pattern as well.

title: Empty scan ranges cause panic

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: size:M
labels.description: This PR changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

body:
SST iterators currently make this check when there are no more fetch tasks:

```rust
assert_eq!(self.next_block_idx_to_fetch, self.block_idx_range.end);
```

This makes sense in the happy path case where we've traversed blocks in order. There's a pathological case that causes this code to panic. If a user scans in such a way that the range's start key > the range's end key, it causes a panic here with something like:

```
---- sst_iter::tests::test_iter_with_start_key_larger_than_end_key stdout ----

thread 'sst_iter::tests::test_iter_with_start_key_larger_than_end_key' panicked at slatedb/src/sst_iter.rs:295:17:
assertion `left == right` failed
  left: 2
 right: 1
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace


failures:
    sst_iter::tests::test_iter_with_start_key_larger_than_end_key
```

I was getting this while doing deterministic simulation testing. I've added a unit test to reproduce and updated the check to allow start blocks to be `>=` end blocks.
